ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I did not a lot about methods in sociology before this, and I confident about talking about them now. I also learned how to develop a project idea and go through the research process.
a brief introduction to some sociology papers
The readings and projects allowed me to familiarize myself with visual research methods and practice applying them.
Learned a lot about methods to conduct sociological research and ways to organize and frame daily sociological observations and discovery
Learned about sociology and its methods and discussed it in cool ways

An understanding of the branch of visual sociology, including observational research methods, qualitative and quantitative research design, and hands-on research project experience. This course is a wonderful overview into a branch of sociology and different from any other course I've taken in sociology at Yale. I gained so much insight from Professor Smith and class discussions, and readings were designed to teach concepts through example.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The reading guides were a big asset to the course because they made the readings easier to tackle and less time-consuming since you could anticipate exactly what discussion would look like. Honestly, the readings were often boring, so having the guides made me not mind doing them.
Less exams because they can be a lot with the papers

This course's reading workload was perfectly balanced, and reading guides allowed students to focus on specific portions of readings relevant to class discussions. Splitting the majority of grade distribution into two individual research projects was nice in spreading out the semester's workload. In-class exams were easy enough and did not provide a large stressor. One course drawback was the pacing increase at the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this, especially since most people will take a course like this to fulfill a methods requirement anyway. Visual Sociology was admittedly offputting at first (because it felt like an obligation) but ended up becoming one of my favorite courses. The readings had breadth to them, so even if you didn't like one reading one week you will inevitably come across a few that are right up your alley. You'll have ample time and support for the projects, and they're a great opportunity to explore your interests.
Yes, you learn a lot about our visual world and sociological research in general in a relatively low stress, engaging and fun way
Yes! If youre interested in visual media or sociology

Yes! Professor Smith is wonderful and obviously very knowledgeable about the course material. Class discussions were engaging and informative - this was a class I never had a desire to skip. I would recommend this class to anyone inside or outside of the sociology major; course topics were varied and very interesting every week.
